title: Effect of LY2062430, an Anti-Amyloid Beta Monoclonal Antibody, on the Progression of Alzheimer's Disease as Compared With Placebo
description_brief:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an age-related degenerative disorder of the brain, characterized by progressive decline in cognitive function and ability to perform activities of daily living, and ultimately can lead to death due to complications of the disease. AD is thought to be caused by an excess of A-Beta amyloid, a sticky protein in the brain that forms amyloid plaques. Treatments that slow the synthesis or deposition of A-Beta amyloid, or that increase clearance, might be expected to slow the progression of AD.

LY2062430 (solanezumab) is a humanized anti-A Beta peptide immunoglobulin G-1 (IgG1) monoclonal antibody being developed for the treatment of AD. The primary hypothesis being tested is that LY2062430 will slow cognitive and functional decline in AD as compared with placebo. Each patient's participation will last approximately 19 months. Patients taking approved AD medications may participate in this study and continue taking these medications during the study.
drug: LY2062430 (solanezumab) — humanized anti‑Aβ (amyloid‑beta) IgG1 monoclonal antibody
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests LY2062430 (solanezumab), described in the protocol as a humanized anti‑Aβ IgG1 monoclonal antibody developed to bind soluble amyloid‑beta and increase its clearance, with the explicit goal of slowing cognitive/functional decline by acting on Alzheimer’s pathology. citeturn0search7turn0search3

Act (key extracted details): Intervention = LY2062430 (solanezumab), a monoclonal antibody targeting amyloid‑beta; comparator = placebo. The trial is framed as a disease‑modifying approach (slowing Aβ deposition/clearing Aβ). citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: Classification — this is a biologic that directly targets Alzheimer’s core pathology (amyloid‑beta), so it fits the 'disease‑targeted biologic' category. Note: later phase‑3 results showed limited clinical benefit in some trials (e.g., EXPEDITION series), but that does not change the intervention's mechanism or category. citeturn0news12turn0search5
